fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Some notes
Fast convergence: Newton's method usually has local quadratic convergence.
Expensive: requires storing and inverting \nabla ^2 f( \mathbf {x}).
Unstable: \nabla ^2 f \succ 0 might not hold for general nonlinear problems.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If f is first-order continuously differentiable, then f is convex iff f(\boldsymbol {y}) \geq f(\boldsymbol {x}) + \langle \nabla f(\boldsymbol {x}), \boldsymbol {y} - \boldsymbol {x} \rangle
If f: \mathbb {R}^n \to \mathbb {R} is twice-differentiable, then f is convex if and only if \nabla ^2 f(\boldsymbol {x}) \succeq 0.

fr:ul.fr:li: Nonnegative weighted sums: if f_1, \ldots , f_n are convex and \alpha _1, \ldots , \alpha _n > 0 then we have f(\boldsymbol {x}) = \sum _{i = 1}^{n} \alpha _i f_i(\boldsymbol {x}) is convex
Pointwise maximum: if f_1, \ldots , f_n are convex then f(\boldsymbol {x}) = \max _i \{f_i(\boldsymbol {x})\} is convex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A function f is \mu -strongly convex if and only if g(\boldsymbol {x}) = f(\boldsymbol {x}) - \frac {\mu }{2} ||\boldsymbol {x}||_2^2 is convex, \forall \boldsymbol {x} \in \mathrm {dom} f.
A problem is smooth if both the objective function and the constraints are differentiable.

Let f: \mathbb {R}^n \to \mathbb {R} be convex. A subgradient of f at \boldsymbol {x}_0 is any \boldsymbol {u} satisfying f(\boldsymbol {x}) \geq f(\boldsymbol {x}_0) + \langle \boldsymbol {u}, \boldsymbol {x} - \boldsymbol {x}_0 \rangle

The subdifferential is the set of all subgradient's of f at \boldsymbol {x}_0. \partial f(\boldsymbol {x}_0) \coloneqq \{\boldsymbol {u} | f(\boldsymbol {x}) \geq f(\boldsymbol {x}_0) + \langle \boldsymbol {u}, \boldsymbol {x} - \boldsymbol {x}_0 \rangle \}
In this section, we cover many random math facts / tools that come up / are useful in later optimization problems.

A symmetric matrix \mathbf {A}\in \mathbb {R}^{n\times n} is positive definite if \mathbf {x}^{\top }\mathbf {A}\mathbf {x}>0 for all nonzero \mathbf {x}\in \mathbb {R}^{n}. It is positive semidefinite (p.s.d.) if \mathbf {x}^{\top }\mathbf {A}\mathbf {x}\geq 0 for all \mathbf {x}\in \mathbb {R}^{n}.

Let \mathbf {A}\in \mathbb {R}^{m\times n} with \operatorname {rank}(\mathbf {A})=r. There exist \sigma _{1}\geq \sigma _{2}\geq \cdots \geq \sigma _{r}>0, and matrices \mathbf {U}\in \mathbb {R}^{m\times r},\ \mathbf {V}\in \mathbb {R}^{n\times r}, with orthonormal columns (\mathbf {U}^{\top }\mathbf {U}=\mathbf {I},\ \mathbf {V}^{\top }\mathbf {V}=\mathbf {I}) such that \mathbf {A}\ =\ \mathbf {U}\mathbf {\Sigma }\mathbf {V}^{\top }\ =\ \sum _{i=1}^{r}\sigma _{i}\mathbf {u}_{i}\mathbf {v}_{i}^{\top }\,,\quad \mathbf {\Sigma }\ =\ \operatorname {diag}\left (\sigma _{1},\cdots ,\sigma _{r}\right ).

Let \mathbf {A}\in \mathbb {R}^{m\times n} with SVD, \mathbf {A}=\sum _{i=1}^{\min \{m,n\}}\sigma _{i}\mathbf {u}_{i}\mathbf {v}_{i}^{\top }. Then an optimal solution to the best rank-r approximation problem \min _{\mathbf {X}}||\mathbf {X}-\mathbf {A}||_{2}\,,\quad \text {s.t.}\quad \text {rank}(\mathbf {X})\ \leq \ r is the truncated SVD of the following form \boxed {\widehat {\mathbf {A}}_{r}\ =\ \sum _{i=1}^{r}\sigma _{i}\mathbf {u}_{i}\mathbf {v}_{i}^{\top }}\,,\ \ \text {if}\ \ \sigma _{r}>\sigma _{r+1}\,,\,\text {it is unique.}

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Suppose m \geq n, then we observe that \left |\left |{\widehat {\mathbf {A}}}_{r}-{\mathbf {A}}\right |\right |_{2}\;=\;\left |\left |\sum _{i=r+1}^{n}\sigma _{i}\mathbf {u}_{i}\mathbf {v}_{i}^{\mathsf {T}}\right |\right |_{2} \leq \sigma _{r+1}
Second, to prove our result, we want to show that \left |\left |\mathbf {B}_{r}-\mathbf {A}\right |\right |_{2}\ \geq \ \sigma _{r+1},\quad \forall \mathbf {B}_{r}\ \text {with}\ \mathrm {rank}(\mathbf {B}_{r})=r. We suppose \ \mathbf {B}_{r}=\widetilde {\mathbf {U}}\widetilde {\mathbf {V}}^{\top },\quad \widetilde {\mathbf {U}}\in \mathbb {R}^{m\times r},\ \widetilde {\mathbf {V}}\in \mathbb {R}^{n\times r}. Note \begin {align*} ||\mathbf {B}_r - A||_2^2 &= \sup _{||\boldsymbol {z}||_2 \leq 1} ||(\mathbf {B}_r - \mathbf {A})\mathbf {z}||_2^2 \\ &\geq ||(\mathbf {B}_r - \mathbf {A})\mathbf {w}||_2^2 \end {align*} Since \widetilde {V} has r columns, then there must be a nontrivial linear combination of the first r{+}1 columns of V, i.e., \mathbf {w}=\gamma _{1}\mathbf {v}_{1}+\cdots +\gamma _{r+1}\mathbf {v}_{r+1} such that \widetilde {V}^{\top }\mathbf {w}=\mathbf {0}\,. Wlog, we can scale \left |\left |\mathbf {w}\right |\right |_{2}=1 and \,\sum _{i=1}^{r+1}\gamma _{i}^{2}=1 Then ||\mathbf {A}-\mathbf {B}_{k}||_{2}^{2}\geq ||(\mathbf {A}-\mathbf {B}_{k})\,\mathbf {w}||_{2}^{2}=||\mathbf {A}\mathbf {w}||_{2}^{2}=\gamma _{1}^{2}\sigma _{1}^{2}+\cdots +\gamma _{r+1}^{2}\sigma _{r+1}^{2}\geq \sigma _{r+1}^{2}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {A}\in \mathbb {R}^{m\times n}. We say the matrix norm is unitary invariant if \left ||\mathbf {A}\right ||_{\sharp }\ =\ \left ||\mathbf {PAQ}\right ||_{\sharp },\quad \forall \ \mathbf {P}\in O(m),\ \mathbf {Q}\in O(n).

Let \mathbf {A}\in \mathbb {R}^{m\times n}. For any p \in [1,+\infty ], the function \left ||\mathbf {A}|\right |_{\mathrm {S}_{p}}\,:=\,\left ||\mathbf {\sigma }(\mathbf {A})|\right |_{p} is a norm on \,\mathbb {R}^{m\times n}.

A differentiable function f(\mathbf {x}) is called smooth iff it has a Lipschitz continuous gradient, i.e., iff L< \infty such that ||\nabla f(\mathbf {x})-\nabla f(\mathbf {z}) ||_{2}\ \leq L ||\mathbf {x}-\mathbf {z} ||_{2},\quad \forall \mathbf {x},\ \mathbf {z}\in \mathbb {R}^{n}

Let f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R} be continuously differentiable. For any fixed \mathbf {x} and \mathbf {y}, we have \,f(\mathbf {y})\,=\,f(\mathbf {x})\,+\,\langle \nabla f(\mathbf {z}(t_{L})),\mathbf {y}-\mathbf {x}\rangle \, for some \mathbf {z}(t_{L})=(1-t_{L})\cdot \mathbf {x}+t_{L}\cdot \mathbf {y} with t_{L}\in (0,1)\,.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Let f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R} be a convex function, then
A local minimizer of f is also its global minimizer. If f is strictly convex, the global minimizer is unique
A point is a global minimizer of f iff \mathbf {0}\ \in \ \partial f(\mathbf {x_{\star }}). If f\in \mathcal {C}^{1}, then \nabla f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})=\mathbf {0} implies that \mathbf {x_{\star }} is a global minimizer.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Want to find \operatorname *{min}_{\mathbf {x}}\ f(\mathbf {x}),\quad \text {s.t.}\quad \mathbf {x}\ \in \ \mathcal {C}. Solve the problem via iterative methods of optimization, which produce a sequence of points \mathbf {x}_{1},\ \mathbf {x}_{2},\ \cdots ,\mathbf {x}_{k},\cdots starting from an initialization \mathbf {x}_{0}.

First-order function value convergence ||\nabla f(\mathbf {x}_k)||_2 \; \leq \; \varepsilon .
For convex functions, this also means convergence to the global minimizer
For nonconvex functions, this only means convergence to a Stationary point (e.g., a local minimizer or a saddle point).

We say the Q-convergence is of order (p \geq 1) and with factor (\gamma > 0), if \exists k_{0}, such that \forall k\geq k_{0}: \boxed {\min _{\mathbf {x_{*}}\in \mathcal {X}}||\mathbf {x_{k}}-\mathbf {x_{*}}||_{2}\ \leq \ \gamma \cdot \left (\min _{\mathbf {x_{*}}\in \mathcal {X}}||\mathbf {x_{k-1}}-\mathbf {x_{*}}||_{2}\right )^{p}.}

We say the R-convergence is of order p\;(\geq 1), \min _{\mathbf {x}_{*}\in \mathcal {X}}||\mathbf {x}_{k}-\mathbf {x}_{*}||_{2}\;\leq \;\rho _{k}, if the sequence \{\rho _{k}\}_{k\geq 1} is Q-convergence of the order p.

Suppose f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R} is convex and smooth with its gradient L-Lipschitz. If we run GD for k iterations with a fixed step size \tau =1/L, it will yield a sequence \left \{\mathbf {x}_{k}\right \}_{k\geq 1} such that
f(\mathbf {x}_{k})-f(\mathbf {x}_{\star })\ \leq \ \frac {L}{2k}\left ||\mathbf {x}_{0}-\mathbf {x}_{\star }\right ||_{2}^{2}\ =\ O(\frac {1}{k}),
Moreover, as k\to +\infty , then \mathbf {x}_{k}\to \mathbf {x}_{\star }.

Suppose the iterates \{\mathbf {x}_{i}\}_{i\geq 0} is generated from a black-box model:
\mathbf {x}_{k+1}\ =\ \mathcal {F}_{k}\left (\left \{\mathbf {x}_{i}\right \}_{i=0}^{k},\ \left \{f(\mathbf {x}_{i})\right \}_{i=0}^{k},\ \left \{\nabla f(\mathbf {x}_{i})\right \}_{i=0}^{k}\right )

For every positive L and R, there exists a convex differentiable f with \nabla f L-Lipschitz, and an initial point \mathbf {x}_{0} satisfying ||\mathbf {x}_{0}-\mathbf {x}_{\star }||_{2}\leq R, such that
f(\mathbf {x}_{k})-f(\mathbf {x}_{\star })\ \geq \ c\frac {LR}{k^{2}}\ =\ \Omega (\frac {1}{k^{2}}),
where \ c>0 is some numerical constant.

Suppose f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R} is convex and smooth with its gradient L-Lipschitz. The iterates \{\mathbf {x}_{k}\}_{k\geq 1} generated by the accelerated GD method satisfy
f(\mathbf {x}_{k})-f(\mathbf {x}_{\star })\ \leq \ \frac {L}{2(k+1)^{2}}\ ||\mathbf {x}_{0}-\mathbf {x}_{\star }||_{2}^{2}\ =\ O(\frac {1}{k^{2}}).
Moreover, as k\to +\infty , then \mathbf {x}_{k}\to \mathbf {x}_{\star }.
For x_{k+1}\ =\ x_{k}\ -\ \tau _{k}\cdot \nabla f(x_{k}) Choose step size by solving \tau _{k}\;=\;\arg \operatorname *{min}_{t\geq 0}\;f({\mathbf {x}}_{k}-t\cdot \nabla f({\mathbf {x}}_{k}))

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Wolfe condition requires evaluating gradient of function each update to \tau _k. However, Armijo Condition only requires evaluating gradient once. Therefore, it is primarily used in practice.
Backtracking is not used in optimizing DNNs because even function evaluation is very expensive.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let the function f(\pmb {x}) be \mu -strongly convex and L-smooth. With backtracking
linesearch, the GD method converges with
f(\pmb {x}_k)-f(\pmb {x}_\star )\ \le \ \left (1-\min \left \{2c_1\mu ,\dfrac {2\alpha c_1\mu }{L}\right \}\right )^k(f(\pmb {x}_0)-f(\pmb {x}_\star ))
where \pmb {x}_\star is the unique minimizer.

Let f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R} be smooth and \mu -strongly convex, and suppose its gradient \nabla f(\mathbf {x}) is L-Lipschitz. Choose a fixed step size \tau _{k}\equiv \tau =\frac {2}{\mu +L}, then
\left ||\mathbf {x}_{k}-\mathbf {x}_{\star }\right ||_{2}\ \leq \ \left (\frac {\kappa -1}{\kappa +1}\right )^{k}\left ||\mathbf {x}_{0}-\mathbf {x}_{\star }\right ||_{2},
where \kappa =\frac {L}{\mu } is the condition number, and \mathbf {x}_{\star } is the minimizer.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Strong convexity is a sufficient but not necessary condition for linear convergene of gradient descent.
